page.title: 01Pasture North of Glastonbury
page.content: The area is almost entirely flat low-lying grassland known locally as "Moors". The soil is of peat and the water table is a metre or two below the level of the ground. The fields are drained with long, wide straight ditches known as "Rhynes" which need to be dug out frequently. These serve as wet-fences for keeping livestock in, and are prettily lined with willow trees. fields are sometimes flooded in winter. It is very sparcely populated, the chief activity being dairy farming with some beef and sheep. Small apple orchards are attached to farms. Cider is made on one farm and sold to the public. fishing is a popular pastime. One of our rarer birds, the heron is frequently seen as are other water birds. Fenny Castle is the site of a motte and Bailey castle.
